questions.text: Limiting amino acids in cereals and pulses, respectively, are
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lysine is often the limiting amino acid in cereals, while methionine is the limiting amino acid in pulses.

  • This is why combining cereals with pulses in diets, such as in traditional dishes like dal with rice, provides a more balanced amino acid profile.

Lysine, threonine (Option A): This option suggests that lysine is the limiting amino acid in cereals, which is correct. However, threonine is not typically the limiting amino acid in pulses. Instead, pulses are generally deficient in methionine, making option A incorrect.

Lysine and Cysteine (Option B): While lysine is indeed a limiting amino acid in cereals, cysteine is not typically the limiting amino acid in pulses. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Threonine and Cysteine (Option D): Threonine is not typically the limiting amino acid in cereals, and cysteine is not typically the limiting amino acid in pulses. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: Normal fluorine content in drinking water
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The normal fluorine content

  • Fluorine is the most abundant halogen in nature.
  • Due to its high reactivity, it is not found in elemental (gaseous) form in nature-only in combined forms.
  • ~96% of fluoride in the body is stored in bones and teeth.
  • It is essential for proper mineralization of bones and the formation of dental enamel.

Sources of Fluorine:

  • Drinking Water
    • Primary source of fluoride for humans.
    • In most parts of India, levels are about 0.5 mg/L.
    • In fluorosis-endemic areas, levels may rise to 3-12 mg/L.
  • Foods
    • Trace amounts present in many foods.
    • Fluoride-rich foods include:
      • Sea fish
      • Cheese
      • Tea

Requirements:

  • In India:
    • Recommended fluoride level in drinking water: 5 - 0.8 mg/L
  • In temperate climates(due to lower water intake):
    • Optimum level: 1 - 2 mg/L

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding fluorosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fluorosis is a condition caused by excessive intake of fluoride over a prolonged period. While fluorosis primarily affects the teeth and bones, it can manifest in various forms depending on the severity of fluoride exposure.

choices.text: 90 ppm at the production level and 60 ppm at the consumer level
30 ppm at the production level and 20 ppm at the consumer level
30 ppm at the production level and 15 ppm at the consumer level
15 ppm at the production level and 30 ppm at the consumer level

questions.text: As per the Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act, what are the prescribed standards for the level of iodisation of salt?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The PFA (Prevention of Food Adulteration) Act lays down standards for the iodization of salt in India to prevent iodine deficiency disorders (IDD). It suggests 30 ppm at the prosutcion level and 15 ppm at the consumer level.

  • Iodine is an essential micronutrient required for the production of thyroid hormones, which are crucial for the proper functioning of the thyroid gland and overall metabolic health.
  • The PFA Act mandates specific levels of iodization for salt at both the production and consumer levels.

questions.text: Daily requirement of iodine in adults
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Daily requirement of iodine in adults is 150 mcg.

Daily Iodine Requirement:

  • Adults→ Recommended daily intake is 150 micrograms (mcg).
  • Pregnancy (as per WHO guidelines)→ Recommended daily intake increases to 250 mcg. This is to support fetal growth and maternal thyroid function. (Option D)
  • A well-balanced dietand iodine-rich drinking water usually meet these requirements.
  • However, in iodine-deficient regions, supplementation or iodised salt may be necessary.

Explanation:

Twin fortified salt is a type of salt that is fortified or enriched with additional nutrients to address specific nutritional deficiencies in populations.

  • It typically contains iodine to prevent iodine deficiency disorders (IDD) and another nutrient, often iron, to address iron deficiency anemia.
  • Iron deficiency is one of the most common nutritional deficiencies worldwide, and fortifying salt with iron can be an effective strategy to improve iron intake and reduce the prevalence of iron deficiency anaemia.

Iodine + Fluorine (Option A): While iodine is commonly added to salt to prevent iodine deficiency disorders, fluorine (fluoride) is not typically added to salt. Fluoride is often added to water supplies or dental products (e.g., toothpaste) to prevent dental caries (cavities), but it is not a common fortificant in salt.

Iodine + Calcium (Option B): Iodine is commonly added to salt to prevent iodine deficiency disorders, but calcium is not typically added to salt as a fortificant. Calcium is an essential mineral, but it is usually obtained from dietary sources such as dairy products, leafy greens, and fortified foods.

Iodine + Chlorine (Option D): Chlorine is not typically added to salt as a fortificant. While iodine is commonly added to salt to prevent iodine deficiency disorders, chlorine is not a nutrient that is added for nutritional purposes. Chlorine is commonly used in water treatment to disinfect water supplies, but it is not a component of twin fortified salt.

choices.text: Prevalence of goitre among school children
Urinary iodine levels among pregnant women

questions.text: The best indicator to monitor the impact of IDDCP is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program (IDDCP)

  • The IDDCPis a public health initiative aimed at eliminating iodine deficiency disorders (IDD) in the population.
  • IDDis primarily caused by inadequate iodine intake and can lead to serious health issues such as:
    • Goitre
    • Cretinism
    • Intellectual disability
  • The program focuses on preventive strategies, including iodized salt consumption and monitoring iodine levels in vulnerable groups.

Urinary Iodine Levels in Pregnant Women:

  • Urinary iodine levelsserve as a direct and sensitive indicator of recent iodine intake.
  • Pregnant womenare particularly at risk due to increased iodine requirements to support fetal brain development.
  • Monitoring these levels:
    • Helps assess iodine statusduring pregnancy.
    • Provides real-time feedbackon the effectiveness of iodine supplementation programs.

Prevalence of goitre among school children (Option A): While goitre prevalence can indicate iodine deficiency in a population, it is not the most sensitive indicator, as goitre formation may take time to develop after iodine deficiency occurs. Additionally, goitre prevalence may not accurately reflect recent changes in iodine intake or the effectiveness of intervention programs.

Iodine levels in soil (Option B): Soil iodine levels may influence the iodine content of food crops, but they do not directly reflect human iodine status. The bioavailability of iodine from soil to plants and ultimately to humans can vary, making soil iodine levels less reliable as an indicator of iodine sufficiency in the population.

Neonatal hypothyroidism (Option D): Neonatal hypothyroidism can result from iodine deficiency during pregnancy, leading to impaired thyroid hormone production in newborns. While neonatal hypothyroidism is a severe consequence of iodine deficiency, it is a late-stage indicator and may not reflect recent changes in iodine intake or the effectiveness of intervention programs.

questions.text: Zinc deficiency is common in children from developing countries due to all the following except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intestinal parasitosis, such as infections with parasites like Giardia lamblia or Ascaris lumbricoides, can lead to nutrient malabsorption and increased nutrient losses through diarrhoea, resulting in micronutrient deficiencies. However, intestinal parasitosis is not directly linked to zinc deficiency.

Causes of Zinc Deficiency:

  • Inadequate intake of animal-source foods: Animal foods like meat, fish, and milk are better sources of bioavailable zinc. Vegetarian or poor diets often lack sufficient zinc. (Option A)
  • High dietary phytate content: Phytates (found in whole grains, legumes, and some vegetables) inhibit zinc absorption. (Option B)
  • Inadequate overall food intake:Common in malnourished children and populations with food insecurity.
  • Increased faecal loss during diarrhoea: Zinc loss is higher during gastrointestinal infections, particularly diarrhoea. (Option D)
  • Liver disease:Associated with reduced zinc levels in circulation.
  • Pernicious anaemia
  • Thalassaemia
  • Myocardial infarction:Clinical conditions that can lower circulating zinc levels.
  • Pregnancy and lactation: Increased physiological demands can lead to deficiency if intake is inadequate.
  • Severe maternal zinc deficiency: Linked to spontaneous abortion and congenital malformations.
  • Zinc-poor diets in children from developing countries:Due to low intake of animal foods and high phytate consumption.

Explanation:

Conditionally essential amino acids are tyrosine and cysteine.

  • Conditionally essential amino acids are those amino acids that are normally non-essential, meaning the body can synthesize them under normal physiological conditions.
  • However, under certain circumstances, such as illness, stress, or metabolic disorders, the body may not be able to produce these amino acids in sufficient quantities, making them essential in those situations.

Leucine and lysine (Option A): Leucine and lysine are essential amino acids, meaning they cannot be synthesized by the body and must be obtained from the diet. They are not conditionally essential because the body always requires them from external sources.

Histidine and arginine (Option B): Histidine and arginine are also essential amino acids that cannot be synthesized by the body and must be obtained from dietary sources. They are not considered conditionally essential because their requirement remains constant regardless of physiological conditions.

Phenylalanine and tryptophan (Option D): Similar to leucine, lysine, histidine, and arginine, phenylalanine and tryptophan are essential amino acids that cannot be produced by the body and must be obtained from the diet. They are not considered conditionally essential because their requirement remains constant under normal physiological conditions.

questions.text: Keshan cardiomegaly occurs due to the deficiency of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keshan disease is a type of cardiomyopathy that primarily affects children and young women. It is characterized by an enlarged heart (cardiomegaly) and can lead to heart failure. The condition was first identified in Keshan County, China, and it's associated with a selenium deficiency.

Selenium

Sources:

  • Foodis the main source of selenium for humans.
  • Selenium content in foodvaries depending on the geographical area where it's grown.
  • Drinking waterusually contains very low levels of selenium, typically less than 0.01 mg/L.

Biological Role:

  • Selenium is essential for humans.
  • It is a key component of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase, which plays a role in antioxidant defense.

Toxicity (Chronic Exposure):

  • Long-term excess intakecan lead to toxicity.
  • Common signs of selenium toxicity appear in the:
    • Nails(brittle or discolored)
    • Hair(loss or changes)
    • Liver(damage or dysfunction)

Copper (Option B): Copper deficiency can lead to various health issues, but it is not specifically associated with Keshan disease. Copper deficiency may result in anaemia, bone abnormalities, and neurological problems, but it does not primarily affect the heart in the same way as Keshan disease.

Zinc (Option C): Zinc deficiency can also cause a range of health problems, including impaired growth and development, immune dysfunction, and skin disorders. However, it is not directly linked to Keshan disease, which is primarily associated with selenium deficiency.

Iron (Option D): Iron deficiency leads to anaemia and other symptoms related to impaired oxygen transport in the body. While iron deficiency can have serious health consequences, including cardiovascular effects, it is not the cause of Keshan disease.

questions.text: Zinc deficiency leads to all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

While some nutrient deficiencies, such as iron deficiency, can lead to an increased appetite (known as polyphagia), zinc deficiency typically does not cause this symptom.

Effects of Zinc Deficiency

  • Growth failure (especially in children)
  • Sexual infantilism in adolescents (Option A)
  • Loss of taste (hypogeusia)
  • Delayed wound healing
  • Increased susceptibility to infections due to impaired immune function (Option B)
  • Spontaneous abortion (in cases of severe maternal deficiency) (Option C)
  • Congenital malformations like anencephaly
  • Low birth weight
  • Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR)
  • Preterm delivery
  • Exacerbation of diarrhoea in children
  • Higher risk of clinical malaria attacks in children
  • Associated with:
    • Liver disease
    • Pernicious anaemia
    • Thalassaemia
    • Myocardial infarction

questions.text: White polished rice causes a deficiency of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

White polished rice causes a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1).

  • When rice is polished to remove the outer bran layers, it also removes a significant portion of the thiamine present in the rice.
  • As a result, consumption of predominantly white polished rice can lead to thiamine deficiency.
  • Thiamine is an essential vitamin that plays a crucial role in energy metabolism, nerve function, and carbohydrate metabolism.
  • A deficiency of thiamine can lead to a condition known as beriberi, which manifests with symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, nerve damage, and cardiovascular issues.

Tryptophan (Option B):

Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and is not directly affected by the polishing process of rice. However, tryptophan deficiency can occur in diets lacking sufficient protein sources.

Riboflavin (Option C): Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is not specifically associated with the consumption of white polished rice. While some loss of riboflavin may occur during rice polishing, it is not as significant as the loss of thiamine.

Protein (Option D): While white polished rice lacks significant protein content compared to unpolished rice, it is not the primary cause of protein deficiency. Protein deficiency is more closely associated with diets lacking diverse protein sources and not specific to white polished rice consumption.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman from a dry state who ingested grass pea for a long time presented with complaints of weakness in both lower limbs, nausea, and fatigue. Over due course of time, she is completely unable to walk. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lathyrus sativus, also known as khesari dal or grass pea, contains a neurotoxic amino acid called β-N-oxalyl-L-α,β-diaminopropionic acid (ODAP). Prolonged consumption of Lathyrus sativus can lead to a neurological disorder known as lathyrism.

  • Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease affecting both humans and animals.

Types:

  • Neurolathyrism (in humans):
    • Affects the nervous system.
      Characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs.
      Commonly seen in adults consuming Lathyrus sativus in large amounts.
  • Osteolathyrism / Odoratism (in animals):
    • Affects the bones, leading to skeletal deformities.

Causative Agent:

  • Caused by excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus, commonly known as:
    Khesari dhal
    Also referred to as Teora dhal, Lak dhal, Batra, Gharas, Matra, etc.
    Seeds are triangular and grey; the dehusked pulse resembles red gram dhal or Bengal gram dhal.

Toxicity:

  • Contains a neurotoxin that affects the spinal cord.
    Although it's a good protein source, the toxin makes it unsafe in large quantities.
    Epidemiology:
  • Affects mostly poor agricultural laborers due to its low cost.
    Diets containing over 30% Lathyrus dhal for 2 to 6 months can lead to neurolathyrism.

Amanita (Option B): Amanita species of mushrooms contain toxins such as amatoxins, which primarily affect the liver and kidneys, leading to organ failure. Symptoms of amatoxin poisoning include gastrointestinal distress, liver failure, and renal failure, but they do not typically present with progressive weakness and paralysis of the lower limbs.

Argemone mexicana (Option C): Argemone mexicana, also known as prickly poppy or Mexican poppy, contains toxic alkaloids that can cause symptoms such as abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. It does not typically cause neurological symptoms like progressive weakness and paralysis.

Ergot alkaloids (Option D): Ergot alkaloids are produced by fungi that infect cereal grains, such as rye. Consumption of ergot-contaminated grains can lead to ergotism, which may present with symptoms such as hallucinations, convulsions, and gangrene due to vasoconstriction. While ergotism can cause neurological symptoms, it does not typically manifest as progressive weakness and paralysis of the lower limbs.

choices.text: Total dietary fat should be limited to 15-30%
Saturated fats should contribute more than 20% of daily energy
Salt intake should be reduced to an average of ≤5 g per day
Protein should make up 10-15% of daily energy intake

questions.text: What is false about a prudent diet?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Saturated fats should contribute no more than 10% of daily energy.

Prudent Diet:

  • Total dietary fat should be limited to 15-30%of total daily energy intake. (Option A)
  • Saturated fatsshould contribute no more than 10% of daily energy; the remainder should come from unsaturated vegetable oils.
  • Avoid excessive intake of refined carbohydrates; choose carbohydrates that are rich in natural fibre(e.g., whole grains, legumes, fruits, vegetables).
  • Limit energy-dense sources like fatsand alcohol, which contribute calories without essential nutrients.
  • Salt intakeshould be reduced to an average of ≤ 5 g per day; current intake in India is about 15 g/day, which is excessive. (Option C)
  • Proteinshould make up 10-15% of daily energy intake. (Option D)
  • Reduce consumption of junk foods(e.g., colas, ketchup, processed snacks) as they provide empty calories with low nutritional value.
  • Diet should be adaptedfor special conditions such as:
    • Growth periods (children, adolescents)
    • Pregnancy and lactation
    • High physical activity levels
    • Medical conditions (e.g., diabetes)
